Award.AwardTitle: Expanding PhET Interactive Science Simulations to Grades 4-8: A Research-based Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will develop and study the impact of science simulations, referred to as sims, on middle school childrens' understanding of science and the scientific process. The project will investigate: 1) how characteristics of simulation design (e.g., interface design, visual representations, dynamic feedback, and the implicit scaffolding within the simulation) influence engagement and learning and how responses to these design features vary across grade-level and diverse populations; 2) how various models of instructional integration of a simulation affect how students interact with the simulation, what they learn, and their preparation for future learning; 3) how these interactions vary across grade-level and diverse populations; and 4) what critical instructional features, particularly in the type and level of scaffolding, are needed.

Working with teachers, the team will select 25 existing sims for study. Teachers and students will be interviewed to test for usability, engagement, interpretation, and learning across content areas. The goal will be to identify successful design alternatives and to formulate generalized design guidelines. In parallel, pull-out and classroom-based studies will investigate a variety of use models and their impact on learning. Ten new simulations will then be developed to test these guidelines.

Products will include the 35 sims with related support materials available for free from a website; new technologies to collect real-time data on student use of sims; and guidelines for the development of sims for this age population. The team will also publish research on how students learn from sims.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF project, the PhET Interactive Simulations group at the University of Colorado Boulder and the AAALab at Stanford University worked together to produce and study learning from interactive simulations designed for middle school science classrooms. Over the course of the grant, we developed 22 high-quality, interactive simulations covering for middle school physical science topics. These simulations are free open educational resource, available at http://phet.colorado.edu. The Build an Atom simulation – currently used over 3 million times per year – provides a good example of this type of interactive learning tool. Visit: http://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulation/build-an-atom.

        In our research on simulation design, we found that designing a simulation with implicit scaffolding results in a particularly powerful and flexible tool for learning.  Implicit scaffolding is where the selection and layout of controls as well as the visual feedback provided by the simulation help cue student interactions and interpretations. These simulations create an open exploratory environment where students can readily engage in exploration, ask their own questions, and discover key scientific ideas. In the Build an Atom simulation, implicit scaffolding is seen, for example, in the choice of buckets that cue students to pull out a proton, the skeleton of the atom that provides building framework, the labels and the mass and charge readouts that immediately respond as students add a proton. Through additional research and technical innovation, we extended these design principles to create an intuitive simulation that works whether you are on a touch or mouse device. 

        These simulations, and their built-in implicit scaffolding, provide new opportunities to create student-centered classroom environments using simulations. Research conducted by CU Boulder, in collaboration with middle school teachers, resulted in a set of general strategies for effective, student-centered sim-based lesson design and facilitation. One example is to begin a lesson with about five minutes of open play, during which students explore the sim without specific instructions. This open play time establishes student agency over their learning, decreases the need for sim-related procedural instructions, and establishes a sense-making mode of student learning that teachers can leverage through facilitation. A collection of teacher professional development resources was created to support effective teacher implementation of sim-based lessons: 
http://phet.colorado.edu/en/teaching-resources/tipsForUsingPhet

        Stanford University further focused on effective instructional patterns for science, concentrating its research with PhET simulations on how to help students learn to look for and think about structural relations in physical phenomena.  The most common ways simulations are used in science instruction are as a teaching demonstration or a set of highly-structured, guided activities.  Basically, students are told the concepts and then they observe or practice.  However, our research has shown that helping students to observe and induce patterns over multiple sets of data is the most beneficial way for them to learn and transfer their understanding to new situations.  We believe this is very consistent to the kind of inductive efforts that scientists use much more often than pure hypothetico-deductive reasoning.
